items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.64 mAOD at 17:15 on 31/03/25 and 4.66 mAOD at 05:15 on 01/04/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 54 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 01/04/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Tuesday's early morning tide at 02:00 on 01/04/2025 is higher than normal, with strong Easterly Force 5 winds. The weather decreases tide table values by 0.11 m. The total forecast tide is 5.98 metres Chart Datum (2.93 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Tuesday afternoon's tide at 14:15 on 01/04/2025 is forecast to be 13 cm lower (2.8 mAOD). No further flood impacts are expected Tuesday afternoon, or through next week. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 01/04/2025.

items.description: Thorney Island to West Itchenor
items.message: The high spring tides which brought elevated water levels along the coast have now passed. Monday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days and accompanied by light South Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather decreases tide table values by -0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 4.99 metres Chart Datum (2.25 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower, no more than minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding could be possible.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: The high spring tides which brought elevated water levels along the coast have now passed. items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible for a few hours either side of high water at 9:45 PM on 31/03/2025 and 10:00 AM om 01/04/2025
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We have closed flood gates at Pill.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
The detailed tidal forecast is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 9:45 PM on 31/03/2025 with a level of 7.58 mAOD with south-easterly force 3 winds.  The second forecast tide is at 10:00 AM on 01/04/2025 with a level of 7.45 mAOD with easterly force 4 winds.  This Flood Alert is likely to be in force until Tuesday 1st April.
This message will be updated in the afternoon of 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding remains possible for this afternoons high tide, Monday 31st March, and tomorrow mornings high tide, Tuesday 1st April. High water at Ilfracombe is at 20:30 BST this afternoon and 08:45 BST tomorrow morning, times of high water will vary along the coast.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 01/04/2025.

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 01:00 AM BST on 01/04/2025, at  the following locations: 

Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 01:30 AM BST 

Eastford Rd, peaking around 02:00 AM BST

Arpley, peaking around 02:00 AM BST 


It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High tides are expected from Monday 31st March through to Wednesday 2nd April which may cause flooding to low lying areas along the coast. 

This flood alert covers the high tide between 00:45 BST on 1/04/2025 and 02:45 BST on 1/04/2025, with the highest tide level expected around 01:45 BST. Tomorrow lunchtimes tide will also be at Flood Alert with the highest tide level expected around 14:00 BST 1/04/25 

Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.

We are monitoring the situation and we are closing flood gates, where needed. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

This message will be updated by 10AM on 1/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Gretna to Silloth
items.message:

This Flood Alert remains in place for the lunchtime tide tomorrow between 13:15 BST on 1/04/2025 and 15:15 BST on 1/04/2025, with the highest level expected around 14:15 BST 1/04/2025. 

Areas most at risk include Coastline from Gretna to Silloth.

We are monitoring the situation and we are closing flood gates, where needed. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

This message will be updated by 10AM on 1/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides from 01 April 2025 may lead to flooding. This flood alert covers the high tide at 13:00 BST on 01/04/2025 with further detail as follows;

Date of FA Threshold being met : 01/04/2025
Time of FA Threshold being met : 12:45 BST
Duration of FA Threshold being exceeded: 60 mins 
Peak Water Level: 5.23mAOD
Time of Peak Water Level: 12:45- 13:45 BST

This message will be updated by 8:00AM on 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding between 6:15pm and 8.30pm today, Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding is expected to affect areas on Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 11:59pm, Monday 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 6:15pm and 8.30pm today, Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9pm Monday 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause flooding from overtopping waves and wind-blown spray between 6:30pm and 9:45pm today, Monday 31/03/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, especially at exposed areas of the coast. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point, including Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. Further flooding is possible over the next few days due to high spring tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9:00PM Monday 31/03/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high spring tides are expected to continue today and tomorrow. Flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary.
Predicted peaks. Sharpness 9.7m to 9.9m at 22:30 on 31/03/2025 and 9.7m to 9.9m at 10:30 on 01/04/2025.
Flooding is not forecast at other gauge sites.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a series of high spring tides are expected to continue today and tomorrow. Flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow.
Predicted peaks: Newport 7.1m to 7.2m at 21:30 on 31/03/2025 and 7.1m to 7.2m at 10:00 on 01/04/2025.
Avonmouth Portbury 7.6m to 7.8m at 21:45 on 31/03/2025 and 7.6m to 7.8m at 10:00 on 01/04/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads that may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: Please note this Alert refers to the tide on Tuesday morning, 01/04/2025. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, but property flooding is not expected. The highest tide level is forecast between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir at 9:45 AM on Tuesday 01/04/2025. Flooding is possible for up to an hour either side of these times. The area most at risk is the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. We are closely monitoring the situation. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Be careful along coastal areas such as paths and low lying roads. The detailed tidal forecast is based on the peak level at Hinkley Point. The forecast high water is at 9:45 AM on 01/04/2025 with a level of 6.40 mAODN and easterly force 4 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level. There may be further tides that require this flood alert. All times are to British Summer Time. This message will be updated by 7:00 PM on 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
River Trent at Alkborough Flats
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Blacktoft river gauge as a result of high spring tides. Flooding is possible for this evening's high tide at 21:00 on 31/03/25 at Blacktoft.  Areas most at risk are the Alkborough Flats. The Blacktoft river gauge is forecast to overtop the lower spillway and result in flooding. 
  
We expect river levels to remain high until after the evening high tide at Blacktoft.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. 
 
Please never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.  

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning 01/04/25.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The previous tide of concern overnight has now passed,  the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on promenades and coastal footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday morning and Tuesday evening. High water at Teignmouth is at 9:30 am and 21:45 pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 5 -6 easterly winds and offshore wave heights up to 1.7m are forecast, to cause rough seas at Torbay and minor flooding is possible at Torbay, Dawlish and Teignmouth.  Expect tides to be around 0.14 – 0.18 meters higher than predicted due to weather conditions.  
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Teignmouth for Tuesday morning is 2.37 mAOD and Tuesday evening is 2.25, this is 0.14 and 0.18 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels remain high due to high groundwater levels in the area. However, following drier conditions, levels are falling very slowly on the Winterbourne Stream and the River Lambourn. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible, especially in the Bagnor area. This week is forecast to remain predominantly dry. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days. Levels will be sensitive to further rainfall.

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated on Monday morning, 07/04/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding as future high tides are expected to reduce significantly.
Tidal conditions are expected to improve this morning and no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels are slowly falling, but remain over the flood alert thresholds. Areas at risk include areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. There is no significant rainfall forecast this week. We are not currently expecting very much drop in the groundwater levels. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 02/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley.  Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level at Preston Candover has fallen by 13cm. At Old Alresford, the level has fallen by 17cm. A small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding in Preston Candover and Old Alresford. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. Over the next 10 days, the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall, and flooding impacts will decrease. Flood impacts are expected to continue through most of April. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 07/04/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 2nd April 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but are falling slowly, at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hursley are high but slowly falling. In the last week, the level has fallen by 47cm. Over the next 10 days, the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Any minor residual flooding impacts will reduce during the coming weeks. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high but slowly falling. In the last week, the level in Clanville has fallen by 30cm. Over the next 10 days, the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Any minor residual flooding impacts will reduce during the coming weeks. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high but continue to slowly fall. In the last week, the level in Oakley has fallen by 30cm. In Deane, we expect a small number of properties to be affected by cellar flooding. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. Over the next 10 days, the weather is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels will continue to slowly fall. If the weather forecast next week looks favourable, this Flood Alert will be removed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 07/04/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message:
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram. This is due to persistent rainfall in December and January which has led to high groundwater levels. 

We are monitoring the flooding that is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. 

There is elevated risk of flooding caused by water emerging from a third party blocked culvert. Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low-lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation.

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 2nd April 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high, but falling slowly, at our Chapel Wood borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. This week is forecast to begin predominantly dry, but more unsettled conditions are expected towards the end of the week. We expect groundwater levels to remain high for the next few weeks and levels are sensitive to sustained periods of rainfall. Low lying land, roads and properties will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, by 01/04/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Areas near the tidal River Welland, tidal River Nene, and the Wash

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, River Nene, The Wash

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Lincolnshire coastline
Precautionary Evacuation Notice area at Snettisham seafront
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. items.description: The north Norfolk coast at Salthouse and east Cley
items.message: Sea levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides, however tides will remain higher than usual for the next few days in association with this set of spring tides. We do not expect to issue any further alerts or warnings. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Coast at St Margaret's at Cliffe, Dover, Folkestone and Sandgate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Coastal conditions are expected to improve this morning and future high tides forecast to be lower. No further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Take care along promenades and coastal roads where standing water may remain.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.description: Bosham and West Itchenor
items.message: The high spring tides which brought elevated water levels along the coast have now passed. Monday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 31/03/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days and accompanied by light South Easterly Force 3 winds. The weather decreases tide table values by -0.1 m. The total forecast tide is 4.99 metres Chart Datum (2.25 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower, no more than minor flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Warning if new instances of property flooding are expected.
